section.title: Multiple cores
section.para: GÃªBR optimizes the execution of loops in multi-core machines

GÃªBR takes advantage of the multi-core feature of most of the recent machines. The execution of repetitive flows can be optimized by this resource. If the Flow has Loops and is parallelizable (given some criteria, shown below), then you can adjust the execution's degree of performance based on the number of processors.
To be considered parallelizable, besides having a loop, a Flow must achieve one, and just one, of these criteria:

itemizedlist.listitem: The Flow does not have an output file;
The output of each step of the loop is not the input of any other step of the loop.

section.para: We choose the amount of processors through an adjustment bar, next to the Run button.
Each level of the adjustment bar corresponds to a a number of cores used by the job.

section.title: Priority of execution
section.para: Computers, nowadays, are multitasked, what means that multiple things can be done at the same time. When many tasks are executed at the same time, the computer can get overloaded and decrease its performance. Seismic processing, particularly, can exhaust the computer resources.
GÃªBR has a feature that overcomes the issue of overloading due to multitasking, by enabling the execution of the Flows in a Low Priority states:
Two options are available:

listitem.para: Low priority (the Flow is going to wait its turn to execute and try not to overload the system)
High priority (the execution of the Flow is going to dispute for the computer resources with the other active programs)

section.para: Technically, when running in "Low Priority" mode, GÃªBR will reduce the run priority of the task, meaning it will tell the computer that "it can wait more important things to be done". This is the case when you have other things to do while you wait your calculations to be done. The "High Priority" mode means GÃªBR will use greater run priority for the task, and that implies it will act as a foreground process, demanding more resources. It's the "I need this done" mode, when you need the job to be finished as soon as possible, and you don't care if it will fight for resources with other programs.

If GÃªBR is the only program executing on your machine, i.e., it doesn't have a challenger for the computer resources, then both states corresponds to the same situation. This is the "nightly job" situation, when (theoretically) no one is using the machines and some jobs are left to be done for the next morning.

section.para: The program Loop (from the category Loops) has a totally different usage compared to the remaining programs from GÃªBR. We are going to see some of these differences.

When we add the program Loop, we can see it always appears in the top of the Flow. That happens to indicate that the Flow is going to be executed more than once, according to the parameters set for the program. (see for further details).

section.title: Multiple machines
section.para: If GÃªBR is connected to multiple machines through the Servers Configuration interface, and the selected Flow is parallelizable (see below the criteria to be parallelizable), then you have the option to run in a distributed way.
To be considered parallelizable, besides having a loop, a Flow must achieve one of these criteria:

listitem.para: The Flow does not have an output file;
The output of each step of the loop is not the input of any other step of the loop.

section.para: In case the Flow is not parallelizable (i.e., does not fit one of the above conditions), GÃªBR will run the job in the best machine at the time of execution (GÃªBR rank them based mainly in availability and speed). In a distributed execution, it may be important to differentiate the Priority mode. When the Flow is parallelizable, it is the split up and distributed between the available machines according to their ranking.
If you want to run a Flow in a specified machine, then he can force the execution by going to Flow Editor tab, as choosing the machine of execution as shown below.
